text.wiki:
Nuremberg ( NEWR-əm-burg; German: Nürnberg [ˈnʏʁnbɛʁk] (listen); Bavarian: Niamberg; East Franconian: Närrnberch or Nämberch, locally Närmberch) is the second-largest city of the German federal state of Bavaria after its capital Munich, and its 511,628 (2016) inhabitants make it the 14th largest city in Germany. On the Pegnitz River (from its confluence with the Rednitz in Fürth onwards: Regnitz, a tributary of the River Main) and the Rhine–Main–Danube Canal, it lies in the Bavarian administrative region of Middle Franconia, and is the largest city and the unofficial capital of Franconia. Nuremberg forms a continuous conurbation with the neighbouring cities of Fürth, Erlangen and Schwabach with a total population of 798,867 (2018), while the larger Nuremberg Metropolitan Region has approximately 3.6 million inhabitants. The city lies about 170 kilometres (110 mi) north of Munich. It is the largest city in the East Franconian dialect area (colloquially: "Franconian"; German: Fränkisch), Nuremberg was one of the host cities of the 2006 FIFA World Cup.
There are many institutions of higher education in the city, including the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg (Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg). With 39,780 students in 2017, it is Bavaria's third-largest and Germany's 11th-largest university, with campuses in Erlangen and Nuremberg and a university hospital in Erlangen (Universitätsklinikum Erlangen). Technische Hochschule Nürnberg Georg Simon Ohm and Hochschule für Musik Nürnberg are also located within the city. Nuremberg Airport (Flughafen Nürnberg “Albrecht Dürer“) is the second-busiest airport in Bavaria after Munich Airport, and the tenth-busiest airport in Germany.
Staatstheater Nürnberg is one of the five Bavarian state theatres, showing operas, operettas, musicals, and ballets (main venue: Nuremberg Opera House), plays (main venue: Schauspielhaus Nürnberg), as well as concerts (main venue: Meistersingerhalle). Its orchestra, Staatsphilharmonie Nürnberg, is Bavaria's second-largest opera orchestra after the Bavarian State Opera's Bavarian State Orchestra in Munich. Nuremberg is the birthplace of Albrecht Dürer and Johann Pachelbel.
Nuremberg was the site of major Nazi rallies, and it provided the site for the Nuremberg trials, which held to account many major Nazi officials.


== History ==


=== Middle Ages ===

The first documentary mention of the city, in 1050, mentions Nuremberg as the location of an Imperial castle between the East Franks and the Bavarian March of the Nordgau. From 1050 to 1571 the city expanded and rose dramatically in importance due to its location on key trade-routes. King Conrad III (reigning as King of Germany from 1138 to 1152) established the Burgraviate of Nuremberg, with the first burgraves coming from the Austrian House of Raab. With the extinction of their male line around 1190, the last Raabs count's son-in-law, Frederick I from the House of Hohenzollern, inherited the burgraviate in 1192.
From the late 12th century to the Interregnum (1254–73), however, the power of the burgraves diminished as the Hohenstaufen emperors transferred most non-military powers to a castellan, with the city administration and the municipal courts handed over to an Imperial mayor (German: Reichsschultheiß) from 1173/74. The strained relations between the burgraves and the castellans, with gradual transferral of powers to the latter in the late 14th and early 15th centuries, finally broke out into open enmity, which greatly influenced the history of the city.
 
Nuremberg is often referred to as the "unofficial capital" of the Holy Roman Empire, particularly because the Imperial Diet (Reichstag) and courts met at Nuremberg Castle. The Diets of Nuremberg played an important role in the administration of the empire. The increasing demands of the Imperial court and the increasing importance of the city attracted increased trade and commerce in Nuremberg. In 1219 Emperor Frederick II granted the Großen Freiheitsbrief ('Great Letter of Freedom'), including town rights, Imperial immediacy (Reichsfreiheit), the privilege to mint coins, and an independent customs policy - almost wholly removing the city from the purview of the burgraves. Nuremberg soon became, with Augsburg, one of the two great trade-centers on the route from Italy to Northern Europe.
In 1298 the Jews of the town were falsely accused of having desecrated the host, and 698 of them were killed in one of the many Rintfleisch massacres. Behind the massacre of 1298 was also the desire to combine the northern and southern parts of the city, which were divided by the Pegnitz. The Jews of the German lands suffered many massacres during the plague pandemic of the mid-14th century.
In 1349 Nuremberg's Jews suffered a pogrom. They were burned at the stake or expelled, and a marketplace was built over the former Jewish quarter. The plague returned to the city in 1405, 1435, 1437, 1482, 1494, 1520 and 1534.

The largest growth of Nuremberg occurred in the 14th century. Charles IV's Golden Bull of 1356, naming Nuremberg as the city where newly elected kings of Germany must hold their first Imperial Diet, made Nuremberg one of the three most important cities of the Empire. Charles was the patron of the Frauenkirche, built between 1352 and 1362 (the architect was likely Peter Parler), where the Imperial court worshipped during its stays in Nuremberg. The royal and Imperial connection grew stronger in 1423 when the Holy Roman Emperor Sigismund of Luxembourg granted the Imperial regalia to be kept permanently in Nuremberg, where they remained until 1796, when the advance of French troops required their removal to Regensburg and thence to Vienna.In 1349 the members of the guilds unsuccessfully rebelled against the patricians in a Handwerkeraufstand ('Craftsmen's Uprising'), supported by merchants and some by councillors, leading to a ban on any self-organisation of the artisans in the city, abolishing the guilds that were customary elsewhere in Europe; the unions were then dissolved, and the oligarchs remained in power while Nuremberg was a free city (until the early-19th century). Charles IV conferred upon the city the right to conclude alliances independently, thereby placing it upon a politically equal footing with the princes of the Empire. Frequent fights took place with the burgraves - without, however, inflicting lasting damage upon the city. After fire destroyed the castle in 1420 during a feud between Frederick IV (from 1417 Margrave of Brandenburg) and the duke of Bavaria-Ingolstadt, the city purchased the ruins and the forest belonging to the castle (1427), resulting in the city's total sovereignty within its borders.
Through these and other acquisitions the city accumulated considerable territory. The Hussite Wars (1419-1434), a recurrence of the Black Death in 1437, and the First Margrave War (1449-1450) led to a severe fall in population in the mid-15th century. Siding with Albert IV, Duke of Bavaria-Munich, in the Landshut War of Succession of 1503-1505 led the city to gain substantial territory, resulting in lands of 25 sq mi (64.7 km2), making it one of the largest Imperial cities.During the Middle Ages, Nuremberg fostered a rich, varied, and influential literary culture.


=== Early modern age ===

The cultural flowering of Nuremberg, in the 15th and 16th centuries, made it the centre of the German Renaissance. In 1525, Nuremberg accepted the Protestant Reformation, and in 1532, the Nuremberg Religious Peace was signed there, preventing war between Protestants and Catholics for 15 years. During the 1552 revolution against Charles V, Nuremberg tried to purchase its neutrality, but the city was attacked without a declaration of war and was forced into a disadvantageous peace. At the Peace of Augsburg, the possessions of the Protestants were confirmed by the Emperor, their religious privileges extended and their independence from the Bishop of Bamberg affirmed, while the 1520s' secularisation of the monasteries was also approved. Families like the Tucher, Imhoff or Haller run trading businesses across Europe, similar to the Fugger and Welser families from Augsburg, although on a slightly smaller scale. 

The state of affairs in the early 16th century, increased trade routes elsewhere and the ossification of the social hierarchy and legal structures contributed to the decline in trade. During the Thirty Years' War, frequent quartering of Imperial, Swedish and League soldiers, the financial costs of the war and the cessation of trade caused irreparable damage to the city and a near-halving of the population. In 1632, the city, occupied by the forces of Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden, was besieged by the army of Imperial general Albrecht von Wallenstein. The city declined after the war and recovered its importance only in the 19th century, when it grew as an industrial centre. Even after the Thirty Years' War, however, there was a late flowering of architecture and culture – secular Baroque architecture is exemplified in the layout of the civic gardens built outside the city walls, and in the Protestant city's rebuilding of St. Egidien church, destroyed by fire at the beginning of the 18th century, considered a significant contribution to the baroque church architecture of Middle Franconia.After the Thirty Years' War, Nuremberg attempted to remain detached from external affairs, but contributions were demanded for the War of the Austrian Succession and the Seven Years' War and restrictions of imports and exports deprived the city of many markets for its manufactures. The Bavarian elector, Charles Theodore, appropriated part of the land obtained by the city during the Landshut War of Succession, to which Bavaria had maintained its claim; Prussia also claimed part of the territory. Realising its weakness, the city asked to be incorporated into Prussia but Frederick William II refused, fearing to offend Austria, Russia and France. At the Imperial diet in 1803, the independence of Nuremberg was affirmed, but on the signing of the Confederation of the Rhine on 12 July 1806, it was agreed to hand the city over to Bavaria from 8 September, with Bavaria guaranteeing the amortisation of the city's 12.5 million guilder public debt.


=== After the Napoleonic Wars ===

After the fall of Napoleon, the city's trade and commerce revived; the skill of its inhabitants together with its favourable situation soon made the city prosperous, particularly after its public debt had been acknowledged as a part of the Bavarian national debt. Having been incorporated into a Catholic country, the city was compelled to refrain from further discrimination against Catholics, who had been excluded from the rights of citizenship. Catholic services had been celebrated in the city by the priests of the Teutonic Order, often under great difficulties. After their possessions had been confiscated by the Bavarian government in 1806, they were given the Frauenkirche on the Market in 1809; in 1810 the first Catholic parish was established, which in 1818 numbered 1,010 souls.In 1817, the city was incorporated into the district of Rezatkreis (named for the river Franconian Rezat), which was renamed to Middle Franconia (German: Mittelfranken) on 1 January 1838. The first German railway, the Bavarian Ludwigsbahn, from Nuremberg to nearby Fürth, was opened in 1835. The establishment of railways and the incorporation of Bavaria into Zollverein (the 19th-century German Customs Union), commerce and industry opened the way to greater prosperity. In 1852, there were 53,638 inhabitants: 46,441 Protestants and 6,616 Catholics. It subsequently grew to become the more important industrial city of Southern Germany, one of the most prosperous towns of southern Germany, but after the Austro-Prussian War it was given to the Prussia as part of their telegraph stations they had to give up. In 1905, its population, including several incorporated suburbs, was 291,351: 86,943 Catholics, 196,913 Protestants, 3,738 Jews and 3,766 members of other creeds.


=== Nazi era ===

Nuremberg held great significance during the Nazi Germany era. Because of the city's relevance to the Holy Roman Empire and its position in the centre of Germany, the Nazi Party chose the city to be the site of huge Nazi Party conventions — the Nuremberg rallies. The rallies were held in 1927, 1929 and annually from  1933 through 1938. After Adolf Hitler's rise to power in 1933 the Nuremberg rallies became huge Nazi propaganda events, a centre of Nazi ideals. The 1934 rally was filmed by Leni Riefenstahl, and made into a propaganda film called Triumph des Willens (Triumph of the Will).
At the 1935 rally, Hitler specifically ordered the Reichstag to convene at Nuremberg to pass the Nuremberg Laws which revoked German citizenship for all Jews and other non-Aryans. A number of premises were constructed solely for these assemblies, some of which were not finished. Today many examples of Nazi architecture can still be seen in the city. The city was also the home of the Nazi propagandist Julius Streicher, the publisher of Der Stürmer.

During the Second World War, Nuremberg was the headquarters of Wehrkreis (military district) XIII, and an important site for military production, including aircraft, submarines and tank engines. A subcamp of Flossenbürg concentration camp was located here, and extensively used slave labour. The city was severely damaged in Allied strategic bombing from 1943 to 1945. On 29 March 1944, the RAF endured its heaviest losses in the bombing campaign of Germany. Out of more than 700 planes participating, 106 were shot down or crash-landed on the way home to their bases, and more than 700 men were missing, as many as 545 of them dead. More than 160 became prisoners of war.On 2 January 1945, the medieval city centre was systematically bombed by the Royal Air Force and the U.S. Army Air Forces and about ninety percent of it was destroyed in only one hour, with 1,800 residents killed and roughly 100,000 displaced. In February 1945, additional attacks followed. In total, about 6,000 Nuremberg residents are estimated to have been killed in air raids.
Nuremberg was a heavily fortified city that was captured in a fierce battle lasting from 17 to 21 April 1945 by the U.S. 3rd Infantry Division, 42nd Infantry Division and 45th Infantry Division, which fought house-to-house and street-by-street against determined German resistance, causing further urban devastation to the already bombed and shelled buildings. Despite this intense degree of destruction, the city was rebuilt after the war and was to some extent restored to its pre-war appearance, including the reconstruction of some of its medieval buildings. Much of this reconstructive work and conservation was done by the organisation 'Old Town Friends Nuremberg'. However, over half of the historic look of the center, and especially the northeastern half of the old Imperial Free City was not restored.


=== Nuremberg trials ===

Between 1945 and 1946, German officials involved in war crimes and crimes against humanity were brought before an international tribunal in the Nuremberg trials. The Soviet Union had wanted these trials to take place in Berlin. However, Nuremberg was chosen as the site for the trials for specific reasons:

The city had been the location of the Nazi Party's Nuremberg rallies and the laws stripping Jews of their citizenship were passed there. There was symbolic value in making it the place of Nazi demise.
The Palace of Justice was spacious and largely undamaged (one of the few that had remained largely intact despite extensive Allied bombing of Germany). The already large courtroom was reasonably easily expanded by the removal of the wall at the end opposite the bench, thereby incorporating the adjoining room. A large prison was also part of the complex.
As a compromise, it was agreed that Berlin would become the permanent seat of the International Military Tribunal and that the first trial (several were planned) would take place in Nuremberg. Due to the Cold War, subsequent trials never took place.Following the trials, in October 1946, several prominent German Nazi politicians and military leaders were executed in Nuremberg.
The same courtroom in Nuremberg was the venue of the Nuremberg Military Tribunals, organized by the United States as occupying power in the area.


== Geography ==

Several old villages now belong to the city, for example Grossgründlach, Kraftshof, Thon, and Neunhof in the north-west; Ziegelstein in the northeast, Altenfurt and Fischbach in the south-east; and Katzwang, Kornburg in the south. Langwasser is a modern suburb.


=== Climate ===
Nuremberg has an oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb) with a certain humid continental influence (Dfb), categorized in the latter by the 0 °C isotherm. The city's climate is influenced by its inland position and higher altitude. Winters are changeable, with either mild or cold weather: the average temperature is around −3 °C (27 °F) to 4 °C (39 °F), while summers are generally warm, mostly around 13 °C (55 °F) at night to 25 °C (77 °F) in the afternoon. Precipitation is evenly spread throughout the year, although February and April tend to be a bit drier whereas July tends to have more rainfall.


== Demographics ==
Nuremberg has been a destination for immigrants. 39.5% of the residents had an immigrant background in 2010 (counted with MigraPro).


== Economy ==
Nuremberg for many people is still associated with its traditional gingerbread (Lebkuchen) products, sausages, and handmade toys. Pocket watches — Nuremberg eggs — were made here in the 16th century by Peter Henlein. Only one of the districts in the 1797-1801 sample was early industrial; the economic structure of the region around Nuremberg was dominated by metal and glass manufacturing, reflected by a share of nearly 50% handicrafts and workers. In the 19th century Nuremberg became the "industrial heart" of Bavaria with companies such as Siemens and MAN establishing a strong base in the city.  Nuremberg is still an important industrial centre with a strong standing in the markets of Central and Eastern Europe. Items manufactured in the area include electrical equipment, mechanical and optical products, motor vehicles, writing and drawing paraphernalia, stationery products and printed materials.
The city is also strong in the fields of automation, energy and medical technology. Siemens is still the largest industrial employer in the Nuremberg region but a good third of German market research agencies are also located in the city. The Nuremberg International Toy Fair is the largest of its kind in the world.


== Tourism ==
Nuremberg is Bavaria’s second largest city after Munich, and a popular tourist destination for foreigners and Germans alike. It was a leading city 500 years ago, but 90% of the town was destroyed in 1945 during the war. After World War II, many medieval-style areas of the town were rebuilt.


===== Attractions =====
Beyond its main attractions of the Imperial Castle, St. Lorenz Church, and Nazi Trial grounds, there are 54 different museums for arts and culture, history, science and technology, family and children, and more niche categories, where visitors can see the world's oldest globe (built in 1492), a 500-year-old Madonna, and Renaissance-era German art. There are several types of tours offered in the city, including historic tours, those that are Nazi-focused, underground and night tours, walking tours, sightseeing buses, self guided tours, and an old town tour on a mini train. Nuremberg also offers several parks and green areas, as well as indoor activities such as bowling, rock wall climbing, escape rooms, cart racing, and mini golf, theaters and cinemas, pools and thermal spas. There are also six nearby amusement parks. The city's tourism board sells the Nurnberg Card which allows for free use of public transportation and free entry to all museums and attractions in Nuremberg for a two-day period.


===== Culinary Tourism =====
Nuremberg is also a destination for food lovers. Culinary tourists can taste the city's famous lebkuchen, gingerbread, local beer, and Nürnberger Rostbratwürstchen, or Nuremberg sausages. There are hundreds of restaurants for all tastes, including traditional franconian restaurants and beer gardens. Also offers 17 vegan and vegetarian restaurants, seven fully organic restaurants. Nuremberg also boasts a two Michelin Star rated restaurant, Essigbrätlein.


===== Pedestrian zones =====
Like many European cities, Nuremberg offers a pedestrian-only zone covering a large portion of the old town, which is a main destination for shopping and specialty retail, including year-round Christmas stores where tourists and locals alike can purchase Christmas ornaments, gifts, decorations, and additions to their toy Christmas villages. The Craftsmen's Courtyard, or Handwerkerhof, is another tourist shopping destination in the style of a medieval village. It houses several local family-run businesses which sell handcrafted items from glass, wood, leather, pottery, and precious metals. The Handwerkerhof is also home to traditional German restaurants and beer gardens.The Pedestrian zones of Nuremberg host festivals and markets throughout the year, most well known being Christkindlesmarkt, Germany's largest Christmas market and the gingerbread capital of the world. Visitors to the Christmas market can peruse the hundreds of stalls and purchase local wood crafts, nutcrackers, smokers, and prune people, while sampling Christmas sweets and traditional gluhwein.


===== Hospitality =====
In 2017, Nuremberg saw a total of 3.3 million overnight stays, a record for the town, and is expected to have surpassed that in 2018, with more growth in tourism anticipated in the coming years. There are over 175 registered places of accommodation in Nuremberg, ranging from hostels to luxury hotels, bed and breakfasts, to multi-hundred room properties. As of 19 April 2019, Nuremberg had 306 AirBnB listings.


== Culture ==

Nuremberg was an early centre of humanism, science, printing, and mechanical invention. The city contributed much to the science of astronomy. In 1471 Johannes Mueller of Königsberg (Bavaria), later called Regiomontanus, built an astronomical observatory in Nuremberg and published many important astronomical charts.
In 1515, Albrecht Dürer, a native of Nuremberg, created woodcuts of the first maps of the stars of the northern and southern hemispheres, producing the first printed star charts, which had been ordered by Johannes Stabius. Around 1515 Dürer also published the "Stabiussche Weltkarte", the first perspective drawing of the terrestrial globe.Printers and publishers have a long history in Nuremberg. Many of these publishers worked with well-known artists of the day to produce books that could also be considered works of art. In 1470 Anton Koberger opened Europe's first print shop in Nuremberg. In 1493, he published the Nuremberg Chronicles, also known as the World Chronicles (Schedelsche Weltchronik), an illustrated history of the world from the creation to the present day. It was written in the local Franconian dialect by Hartmann Schedel and had illustrations by Michael Wohlgemuth, Wilhelm Pleydenwurff, and Albrecht Dürer. Others furthered geographical knowledge and travel by map making. Notable among these was navigator and geographer Martin Behaim, who made the first world globe.
Sculptors such as Veit Stoss, Adam Kraft and Peter Vischer are also associated with Nuremberg.
Composed of prosperous artisans, the guilds of the Meistersingers flourished here. Richard Wagner made their most famous member, Hans Sachs, the hero of his opera Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg. Baroque composer Johann Pachelbel was born here and was organist of St. Sebaldus Church.
The academy of fine arts situated in Nuremberg is the oldest art academy in central Europe and looks back to a tradition of 350 years of artistic education.
Nuremberg is also famous for its Christkindlesmarkt (Christmas market), which draws well over a million shoppers each year.  The market is famous for its handmade ornaments and delicacies.


=== Museums ===
 
Germanisches Nationalmuseum
House of Albrecht Dürer
Kunsthalle Nürnberg
Kunstverein Nürnberg
Neues Museum Nürnberg (Modern Art Museum)
Nuremberg Toy Museum
Nuremberg Transport Museum


=== Performing arts ===

The Nuremberg State Theatre, founded in 1906, is dedicated to all types of opera, ballet and stage theatre. During the season 2009/2010, the theatre presented 651 performances for an audience of 240,000 persons. The State Philharmonic Nuremberg (Staatsphilharmonie Nürnberg) is the orchestra of the State Theatre. Its name was changed in 2011 from its previous name: The Nuremberg Philharmonic (Nürnberger Philharmoniker). It is the second-largest opera orchestra in Bavaria. Besides opera performances, it also presents its own subscription concert series in the Meistersingerhalle. Christof Perick was the principal conductor of the orchestra between 2006–2011. Marcus Bosch heads the orchestra since September 2011  .
The Nuremberg Symphony Orchestra (Nürnberger Symphoniker) performs around 100 concerts a year to a combined annual audience of more than 180,000. The regular subscription concert series are mostly performed in the Meistersingerhalle but other venues are used as well, including the new concert hall of the Kongresshalle and the Serenadenhof. Alexander Shelley has been the principal conductor of the orchestra since 2009.
The Nuremberg International Chamber Music Festival (Internationales Kammermusikfestival Nürnberg) takes place in early September each year, and in 2011 celebrated its tenth anniversary. Concerts take place around the city; opening and closing events are held in the medieval Burg. The Bardentreffen, an annual folk festival in Nuremberg, has been deemed the largest world music festival in Germany and takes place since 1976. 2014 the Bardentreffen starred 368 artists from 31 nations.


=== Cuisine ===

Nuremberg is known for Nürnberger Bratwurst, which is shorter and thinner than other bratwurst sausages.
Another Nuremberg speciality is Nürnberger Lebkuchen, a kind of gingerbread eaten mainly around Christmas time.


== Education ==

Nuremberg offers 51 public and 6 private elementary schools in nearly all of its districts. Secondary education is offered at 23 Mittelschulen, 12 Realschulen, and 17 Gymnasien (state, city, church, and privately owned). There are also several other providers of secondary education such as Berufsschule, Berufsfachschule, Wirtschaftsschule etc.


=== Higher education ===
Nuremberg hosts the joint university Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, two Fachhochschulen (Technische Hochschule Nürnberg and Evangelische Hochschule Nürnberg), an art school (Akademie der Bildenden Künste Nürnberg), and a music conservatoire (Hochschule für Musik Nürnberg). There are also private schools such as the Akademie Deutsche POP Nürnberg offering higher education.


== Main sights ==

Nuremberg Castle: the three castles that tower over the city including central burgraves' castle, with Free Reich's buildings to the east, the Imperial castle to the west.
Heilig-Geist-Spital. In the centre of the city, on the bank of the river Pegnitz, stands the Hospital of the Holy Spirit. Founded in 1332, this is one of the largest hospitals of the Middle Ages. Lepers were kept here at some distance from the other patients. It now houses elderly persons and a restaurant.
The Hauptmarkt, dominated by the front of the unique Gothic Frauenkirche (Our Lady's Church), provides a picturesque setting for the famous Christmas market. A main attraction on the square is the Gothic Schöner Brunnen (Beautiful Fountain) which was erected around 1385 but subsequently replaced with a replica (the original fountain is kept in the Germanisches Nationalmuseum). The unchanged Renaissance bridge Fleischbrücke crosses the Pegnitz nearby.
The Gothic Lorenzkirche (St. Laurence church) dominates the southern part of the walled city and is one of the most important buildings in Nuremberg. The main body was built around 1270–1350.
The even earlier and equally impressive Sebalduskirche is St. Lorenz's counterpart in the northern part of the old city.
The church of the former Katharinenkloster is preserved as a ruin, the charterhouse (Kartause) is integrated into the building of the Germanisches Nationalmuseum and the choir of the former Franziskanerkirche is part of a modern building.
Other churches located inside the city walls are: St. Laurence's, Saint Clare's, Saint Martha's, Saint James the Greater's, Saint Giles's, and Saint Elisabeth's.
The Germanisches Nationalmuseum is Germany's largest museum of cultural history, among its exhibits are works of famous painters such as Albrecht Dürer, Rembrandt, and Ernst Ludwig Kirchner.
The Neues Museum Nürnberg is a museum for modern and contemporary art.
The Walburga Chapel and the Romanesque Doppelkapelle (Chapel with two floors) are part of Nuremberg Castle.
The Johannisfriedhof is a medieval cemetery, containing many old graves (Albrecht Dürer, Willibald Pirckheimer, and others). The Rochusfriedhof or the Wöhrder Kirchhof are near the Old Town.
The Chain Bridge (Kettensteg), the first chain bridge on the European continent.
The Tiergarten Nürnberg is a zoo stretching over more than 60 hectares (148 acres) in the Nürnberger Reichswald forest.
There is also a medieval market just inside the city walls, selling handcrafted goods.
The German National Railways Museum (in German) (an Anchor Point of ERIH, The European Route of Industrial Heritage) is located in Nuremberg.
The Nuremberg Ring (now welded within an iron fence of Schöner Brunnen) is said to bring good luck to those that spin it.
The Nazi party rally grounds with the documentation-center.


== Transport ==
The city's location next to numerous highways, railways, and a waterway has contributed to its rising importance for trade with Eastern Europe.


=== Railways ===

Nürnberg Hauptbahnhof is a stop for IC and ICE trains on the German long-distance railway network. The Nuremberg–Ingolstadt–Munich high-speed line with 300 km/h (186 mph) operation opened 28 May 2006, and was fully integrated into the rail schedule on 10 December 2006. Travel times to Munich have been reduced to as little as one hour. The Nuremberg–Erfurt high-speed railway opened in December 2017.


=== City and regional transport ===

The Nuremberg tramway network was opened in 1881.  As of 2008, it extended a total length of 36 km (22 mi), had six lines, and carried 39.152 million passengers annually.  The first segment of the Nuremberg U-Bahn metro system was opened in 1972. Nuremberg's trams, buses and metro system are operated by the VAG Nürnberg (Verkehrsaktiengesellschaft Nürnberg or Nuremberg Transport Corporation), itself a member of the VGN (Verkehrsverbund Grossraum Nürnberg or Greater Nuremberg Transport Network).
There is also a Nuremberg S-Bahn suburban metro railway and a regional train network, both centred on Nürnberg Hauptbahnhof.
Since 2008, Nuremberg has had the first U-Bahn in Germany (U2/U21 and U3) that works without a driver. It also was the first subway system worldwide in which both driver-operated trains and computer-controlled trains shared tracks.


=== Motorways ===
Nuremberg is located at the junction of several important Autobahn routes. The A3 (Netherlands–Frankfurt–Würzburg–Vienna) passes in a south-easterly direction along the north-east of the city. The A9 (Berlin–Munich) passes in a north–south direction on the east of the city. The A6 (France–Saarbrücken–Prague) passes in an east–west direction to the south of the city. Finally, the A73 begins in the south-east of Nuremberg and travels north-west through the city before continuing towards Fürth and Bamberg.


=== Airport ===
Nuremberg Airport has flights to major German cities and many European destinations. The largest operators are currently Eurowings and TUI fly Deutschland, while the low-cost Ryanair and Wizz Air companies connect the city to various European centres. A significant amount of the airport's traffic flies to and from mainly touristic destinations during the peak winter season. The airport (Flughafen) is the terminus of subway line 2; it is the only airport in Germany served by a subway.


=== Canals ===
Nuremberg is an important port on the Rhine–Main–Danube Canal.


== Sport ==


=== Football ===
1. FC Nürnberg, known locally as Der Club (English: "The Club"), was founded in 1900 and currently plays in the Bundesliga. The official colours of the association are red and white, but the traditional colours are red and black. They won their first regional title in the Southern German championship in 1916 closely followed by their first national title in 1920. Besides the eleven regional championships they won they were the German championship for a total of seven times. With this they held the record for the most German championship titles until 1986 when the current record holder FC Bayern München surpassed them.  The current chairmen are Nils Rossow and Robert Palikuca. They play in Max-Morlock-Stadion which was refurbished for the 2006 FIFA World Cup and accommodates 50,000 spectators. 

German Champion: 1920, 1921, 1924, 1925, 1927, 1936, 1948, 1961, 1968
German Cup: 1935, 1939, 1962, 2007TuS Bar Kochba is a league that was founded in 1913 as a social-sport club for the Jewish community in Nürnberg. Established as the "Jewish Gymnastics and Sports Club Nuremberg", the league was dissolved by the Nazi party in 1939. It was reformed in 1966. The club plays in the senior A-league of the Bavarian Football Association.


=== Basketball ===
The SELLBYTEL Baskets Nürnberg played in the Basketball Bundesliga from 2005 to 2007. Since then, teams from Nuremberg have attempted to return to Germany's elite league. The recently founded Nürnberg Falcons BC have already established themselves as one of the main teams in Germany's second division ProA and aim to take on the heritage of the SELLBYTEL Baskets Nürnberg. The Falcons play their home games at the Halle im Berufsbildungszentrum (BBZ).

Impressive historical monument with great views over the city of Nuremberg. Definitely worth a visit.

Walked by konnigstrasse and walked up the castle. Beautiful walk thru the allies and cafes.. you can see all the colourful cafes full of people having beer and wine.. as you reach the top, you get a panoramic view of the city. It is a tough walk uphill for people having health

This castle is beautiful, be prepared for a steep walk and possibly a large quantity of steps. This area of Nuremberg is very picturesque. The museum is worth a look at but a lot of the signs are in Germany only, so unsure of what you are looking at.
Really loved walking around here! DIdn't pay to go into the museum, but just strolling around it was a very pleasant and enjoyable experience. Great view and nice incline workout going up!

Loved the old castle plenty of history and well designed. The old well is worth the visit. The staff were very friendly and helpful.
Worth going up to the castle for the views over Nuremberg. We had our packed lunch on a bench looking over the city. Quite a special place to visit and a lovely old castle too

a must for everyone who visits Nürnberg. An opportunity to learn a bit of hisotry and have a great look over the city.

Nuremberg's imperial castle. Huge and quite impressive you see it from far cause it's built upon a hill. The new part of the city is developed around it. Once the residence of the emperor, later a military spot.

We did not pay to go inside to the exhibitions, but you can walk around most of the castle anyway. It is a lovely complex, well worth the walk up the hill. Lots of fantastic architecture to admire.

Nice and well maintained, we only had the chance and time to enjoy night and daily view. We didn't visit the inside. The area around it is nice too.

Did not pay for entry into whole complex. Not sure it would be much to see. The walk up & view from above well worth the steep climb, not for unfit.

The Nürnberg castle is well restored and well kept. If you are a history person then this is a must. All explanations are in German so you need to get an audio guide if you need another language.
Not far from our hotel, we walked early in the morning up to the castle. Great views of the city, nice exhibition. Climb the tower!

I love castles and history , so places like this is a must visit for me . This is not as big or grand as other palace but it's still beautiful and very interesting place to visit . It was a freezing day but still worth a visit .
Visited the whole place of this castle. Great and interesting . Nice for photography. Beautiful town view.

Very interesting place. Not the most spectacular castle but still very intriguing and great location

We were so thrilled to experience this,. Well laid out and cool inside ina hot day, shame they were setting up for a choir otherwise would have appreciated the quiet.

This is a pretty church to walk through is you are exploring the old town of Nurnberg. The church is beautiful to look at, and has good details and photos of the history of the church during WW2 and showing where they had to come from. Entrance is free, but donation is suggested
beautiful church; it was nice visiting nuremberg, we loved it, and to say the truth i was not expecting that.

The most beautiful church I've ever seen. They let you take pics inside and some of the stain glass inside shows the date on them I remember one form 1435 I think the date says. A lot of beautiful and very old paintings and carvings inside from hundreds of years ago. A must see
Very nice cathedral with photos and samples of the destruction it had. Little store on the way out. People has to access through the right side door. Easy to find parking lot nearby
Large Catholic Cathedral with pretty nice gothic architecture, at a central place of the city. It is an impressive one from the outside, as well as from the inside space.

Beautiful medieval gothic style church dedicated to Saint Lawrence. The west facade is richly articulated, reflecting the wealth of the Nuremberg citizens.
In the heart of the old town there is this gothic church. You can easily find it and there are nearby many restaurants and shops and station of the underground. You don't need a ticket to entry

Its a beautiful church in the city center of Nuremberg. The view of it increases if its a sunny day when the sunshine is on the walls of the church. The church is an old one but has been well maintained.
Has to be on your list if visiting this beautiful city....the stained glass windows are amazing, such an impressive church..
Surprisingly spoilt and quite peaceful when I visited on May Day. Try to go when the sun is shining so you get the most enjoyment from the windows.
The interior is beautiful with amazing Rose window and stone work. The chandeliers were also something to really cherish

Just walking around the town and sitting on the stairs of lorenz church people passing by its the best experience one can have

Very big church right on the middle of kings street, nice place to visit, the church is very close to many shopping centers and restaurants , highly recommend to give short visit

From the outside its very beautiful, unfortunately we did not have time to venture inside but at night lit up it looks fabulous too

Enjoyed visiting St Lorenz, but we love visiting churches whenever we travel. This is located in the heart of Old Town. Awesome structure but you can see that it has been rebuilt after the war, It seems that some updates are still occurring. The organ is amazing. The pews

Lovely church, many stunning pieces and atmosphere. Right in the centre of the Old Town and accessible for all.

You know the story by now; built, bombed, rebuilt. Worth seeing, not least for the surviving medieval paintings.
Well it is a church, nothing extra, but the entrance fee is voluntary. What I found interesting was interactive screens placed inside, that kids were using to get more information about the place.

It is a beautiful church with lovely art and stained glass windows. There was also an organist playing when we visited, i'm not sure if that's normal or if we were just lucky to be there when he was practising but it definitely added to the experience.

One of the most beautiful churches I've seen so far. Really worth the visit. From the main station only 700 meters away. A must visit!

Impressive both from the outside and the inside. Gothic feel. Take a look at the pictures of WWII. The organ is impressive. In the middle of the shopping district and surrounded by various stalls of food.

i have been here many times. what i like most the old street. i can spend half day shopping too. Because many super market and department stores nearby. Best regards, Dr. Vorravee Pattaravongvisut Man on the Move

Although we didn't go in, we marvelled at this amazing church from the outside. Walking round Nuremberg is such a lovely experience and this one of the many highlights as we walked through this amazing city.

Amazingly beautiful Gothic church built in the later part of the 1200's and early 1300's. The Annunciation, a large structure above the altar, is both striking and worth a stop to visit. So many churches in Nuremberg, St. Lorenz is quite impressive.
Reachable by walking , beautiful church to contemplate during a sunny morning , checking passing people and listening to birds surrounding

Nice church, also a great point to meet. It is not too big so you could easily walk in few minutes. Simple and beautiful

Amazing Church, located in the centre of Nuremberg, close to all the other attractions. Worth a visit.

Very nice place to visit and as well the the popular Christmas market and the shops at the center. Will be back again. Love it!

Awesome interior such a lot to see allow at least half an hour to see it all.. Don't miss the the ceiling and stay for organ concert if they are on.

worth to visit this church come with great structure and interior also with lots of historical items to view

Well worth seeing if your into old architecture , and buildings , the details of the work in side and outside are amazing something lacking in today's modern buildings

this is a regular German gothic church, nothing spectacular, but it is quiet, in the middle of the Old Town and has a nice architecture.

What a nice church so peaceful and amazing. All you need is just stay there in silence and admire all of it

Very beautiful with the complicated nicety. But i could'nt see the opening time of the church. It seems be very weird...

Probably a rather niche review - but if you're interested in Heraldry, and the painting of Hatchments this is one to check out! Bavarian Hatchments tending to the three dimensional and incredibly detailed. Really beautiful church.
While visiting the church there was mid-day concert played by the very talented organist which played Bach, Vivaldi and other composers. One dreamy hour.
Beautiful architecture and amazing place to visit. Both inside and outside, this church is a really great place to visit.
wander around Nurnberg, and, stop in to see the old churches. I think you can easily check out this on your own, while, in Old Town.
Very silence and peaceful place. I donate 1 euro for kids who the church support to. 很安靜平靜的教堂，適合當紐倫堡的開始。 裡面有點蠟燭募款的活動，是給教堂一直以來幫助的孩童， 主要用做上學用途，可以用一歐元給予支持
A very Nice church! They will ask you about 2€ to help them support the church, what costs a lot. You can also find a little Shop inside, where you can buy nice postal cards.
One of three churches in the centre of the old city this one being in the south. Well worth a visit if in Nuremberg.
Great photo oppurtunities and of course the Christmas markets in front during the holidays make this a worthwhile visit.
We were blown away by the beauty of this church and could not stop taking photos! It is one of our favorite landmarks in Nuremberg

Looking at this church one is overawed by its artistic beauty and by the richness of the architectural elaboration. It's of gothic style and was built in the 13th and 14th centuries. The west façade contains a sumptuous rose-window which constitutes the upper part of the

We loved St. Lorenz. I took a ton of photos and could have probably taken even more. The detail inside and the craftsmanship is not something that you see anymore and in the U.S. we do not have anything with this much history. It was absolutely spectacular!
We popped in on the way to shopping for a short visit. It's a beautiful big church, a must see in Nuremberg
My wife says a much see. We love to visit churches. This has unique paintings and sculptures not seen elsewhere. My favorite is Mary playing with Jesus.

September first, I arrived for the very first time to Nüremberg, next day I was taken by friends for a walk in Altstadt (old city). The most attractive building in the whole heart of the city is definitely St. Lorenz Kirche. This church is situated in the pedestrians area and is

Beautiful church but then so are all the churches in Nuremburg. The staff has done a nice job explaining the repairs made after the war. And the interior serves as a nice backdrop for various art works.

If it is your first church to see in Europe, you will be impressed. However, if you have visited a number of churches it is not so impressive. What was impressive was how it has been rebuilt after destruction of World War 2 bombings - we were hard pressed to pick old from new.
The architecture is amazing and it shows a very nice renaissance style church. There is a donation box at the door of most churches in Germany. Help them with the upkeep drop some change in.
You can't help but feeling small when entering this amazing gothic cathedral. It has been rebuilt after the war in great detail.
The church is very beautiful and centrally located! We went to see the Christmas markets and it was really beautifully lit up!

A must-see in Nuremberg's old city. Pretty on the outside, but inside are two spectacular works: hanging from the ceiling is the Engelsgruß or Englischer Gruß (Annunciation/Angelic Greeting), a wood sculpture by Veit Stoss; and set against a column, the Sakramentshaus
This is a remarkable church, for architecture and contents, particularly the altarpieces, the tabernacle, the hanging annunciation, and the glass. Leave time, don't rush.

We attended a Christmas concert here while traveling in Nurnberg. I've always wondered if the acoustics in these old cathedrals would work and was pleasantly surprised to find they do! Best part of the concert was the heated seats - would have been cold without them!

This is an easy 1 hour stroll inside with time to look at the amazing ceiling, the altar, the pedestals, and the whole inside. The only issue we had was that the hanging lights were sometimes right where we wanted to photograph and they are not from the right time. However, it

This church is easy to get to (Lorenz underground station), and well worth a visit. As it's right next to the market, if you are visiitng the Christmas market then you can just pop in for a bit of spiritual refreshment!
Nice to visit and enjoy the many historic buildings in Nuremberg, central in the city, just been outside didn't get to enter, but quite a building.

A wonderful old church. Built from 1250 to 1477. A bit disappointed that stained glass windows only went part way up windows. However that's a minor point. Majestic magnificence with ornate carvings abounding. It's always impressive when you enter and the ceiling is a couple of

Although our travel group had come to Nuremberg for the Christkindlesmarkt, which is delightful, we found our visit to Saint Lorenz Church equally memorable. The size and decoration of the building are amazing and even though it is well visited by tourists it maintains an

This is a place I used to live-just resisted. This is a marvelous monument to man overcoming war. This church was seriously damaged in WW 2, but has been restored very well. Great design, great wood carvings. Worth seeing.

A beautiful church inside and out, full of works of art preserved from the WWII bombing by being hidden away in caves under the castle. It has the feel of a Catholic church with all its statues and paintings but it isn't, Nurnberg having turned Protestant without all the

An interesting church. As many before me have said, it's more interesting on the outside rather than the inside. But it's worth a visit. When I visited it, a mass was about to start. The sound of organ filled the whole building. Magic.

This is my favourite of the city's cathedrals. With an immense high nave. The artwork and stained glass windows are great, but I think the best is the large circular wooden carving by Viet Stoss, hanging over the altar.
Damaged in the war, Lorenz Church has been rebuilt to it's former glory. Magnificent views of the ceiling etc can be seen.
Beautiful church before inside and out. The stain glass windows and exterior detail particular are very impressive
WAKING into three walled city this church steeple stands out a deal caches your the tiob. Go inside for a magnificent feeling of three old world.
A beautiful Gothic church that is more fascinating architecturally on the outside than on the inside but well worth the visit.
wonderful church in the city center of Nuremberg. The nearby market is also good and you can spend a great time roaming around here in any day....

A beautiful church with loads of history. Would recommend that in order to fully appreciate the history yo go on a guided tour of the city and make are this church is included, our tour guide told us really interesting elements not covered in a tourist guide book.
In my opinion, it is the most eminent and beautiful churches in Nuremberg! It is accessible by subway, station Lorenzkirche.
Very beautiful inside - this place just takes a few minutes to visit as you explore town. We wanted to climb the towers but they are closed in winter (Nov to Mar I think). Worth a quick stop
In the middle of the city, and what a sight it is. Beautiful architecture and surroundings. Definitely worth spending some time at.
Even though I'm not a major Church goer as a tourist, this is quite a visit. I have been there a couple of times and its huge and fascinating. Right in the center of the city too !
It looks awesome, kinda similar with the one in florence. The ghotic style is very nicely integrated and it fits perfect with tje town's arhitecture.
cathedrals in Germany are everywhere but each is more beautiful than the last. Take the time to visit each one and do your own comparison. This one is one to see.
A very beautiful church in the center of Nürnberg. It is worth a visit, when visiting the historical center of the city.
Amazing Lutheran church with a rich history and amazing rebuilding after the allies bombing during WWII.
ancient buiding almost totally rebuilt from the ancient rubble after WW2 bombing. Impressive, soaring germanic gothic and pious
The historic Nuremberg is a very lively area in the evening. The church is a beautiful structure in the center of town. We enjoyed looking at the architectural details of the church.
A very nice Sunday Eucharist service here with guest choir from Hereford Cathedral rounded off my trip to Nürnberg.
A beautiful old church. Reminds you of history within its walls. Its right in the city centre, so you can't miss it.

As many other places & buildings in the old town of Nurenberg, also this beautiful historical church was damaged at the end of 2. World War by bombing attact. There also other church worth to inspect & study just 5 min walk.

Free to tour. Lots to see in the church. I did not find any information handouts, brochures, etc that provided info about the history of the church. But still beautiful to look at. I personally like to know a little of the history.
Is nice church inside is very quiet and cold , we can see many statues broken by 2 world war very interesting
A nice example of an old church. A little dark but very good visit. Worth the half hour to see the entire thing.
standing tall, impressive, best visited at night. great to listen to the bells. rest of old town just around
We not only were inspired by the majestic interior but arrived just in time for a wonderful organ concert, Pictures presented helped appreciate reconstruction from WW II

This medieval church (once Catholic as it was part of the Holy Roman Empire) became one of the first Lutheran churches in 1525. Today, it is one of the most prominent churches of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Bavaria. It is a repository for medieval sacred artwork and
Whenever I visit this church, it gives me deep inner peace. Stained glasses in the church must be seen.
It's a very big, very beautiful church. There's a lot of beautiful stone and woodwork. The statues are works of art. The hall is immense! Make sure to look for the smiling Madonna!

St. Lorenz (St. Lawrence), an Evangelical Lutheran Church, is a Gothic church that was damaged during World War II bombing raids. The church was restored with two spires. According to the information plaque, St. Lawrence has the largest organ installed in a Protestant church
The St. Lorenz Church is on of the 3 churches not to be missed in Nuremberg. During a city walking tour you wont miss it.

I found St. Lorenz far more awe-inspiring than St. Sebaldus. Take time to look at the many works of art and statuary that were saved from the bombing and now can be found there again. The architecture is amazing. Do not miss this!

Went to all of the churches in Nuremberg and they were worth it. This one was absolutely beautiful and I would not miss it--the architecture is amazing, We visited during the Christmas markets and there was all kind of activity in the the town square with excellent food and
The rebuilt church of St. Lawrence is gorgeous inside and out. Make sure you see the post bombing pictures of the church. Crazy. It was also my reference point for navigating the city.

St. Lorenz is located in central Nuremburg and is easily accessible. The beauty of the outside of building is paralleled by the beauty inside. The restoration after the Second World War is remarkable.

Towards the very end of WW2 Nuremberg was the scene of a bitter 4 day battle between the Americans and the Germans, many of them Nazis, defending what had been a cultural center of the Third Reich. Sadly, the old center of Nuremberg was reduced to rubble in the process. The St

St Lawrence's Church located in Lorenzer Platz in the Old City is definitely worth visiting. It is a Medieval church which was badly damaged in the 2nd World War but subsequently reconstructed. It contains some beautiful stained glass windows. The vaulted ceiling is unbelievably
This is a beautiful landmark in the city square. The reconstruction of the city after the war is truly remarkable and this is no exception!

St. Lorenz is a medieval church in the Nuremberg Altstadt (Old City) dedicated to Saint Lawrence. The church was badly damaged during the Second World War and later restored, and remains a beautiful building. The site is well worth a visit during a trip to Nuremberg. The view
Beautifully restored ancient church that was almost completely destroyed in WW2. Holds some impressively ancient art
I love to look at old building and Europe and Germany has so many beautiful churches. A must see if you are in Nuremberg.

The magnificent façade of double towers, rose window and portal area is wonderful to see. Badly damaged in the war, it has been beautifully restored. Three aisles dominate the interior. Standing at the back of the central one the vista to the altar is most impressive. A
Beautiful old Lutheran church that has been rebuilt after the war. Cost is around 2€ Donation per person. We got a 3D puzzle as a souvenir for 12€ from the gift shop.
-free to enter -perfect location -nice view -christmas market so close - had a beautiful day in Nuremberg, loved the city
Was in Nuremburg for holiday. Saw this big medieval church. Enjoyed the history and the architecture of the building.

What a wonderful church! a must do in Nuremberg, not to mention that it's free but it is also a fabulous work of arquitecture in reverence to Faith. Considering that it was very much damaged in the aftermath of WWII heavy bombardment it is now restored to a point that you do not

By chance, there was a free, midday, 40-minute organ concert during my visit to Nuremberg. Marvellous! I'm not sure that I might have seen its wonderful, light, Gothic interior otherwise, as it seems not to be open much at other times. Read the outside notice boards for

Absolutely beautiful. I would say the second most beautiful church in Europe, after Seville Cathedral. The underground stops right outside it so use this stop to see the ancient city and you know you won't miss standing in awe of it!
Pretty church to stop in. Amazing to see the total destruction that happened during the war and then to be able to rebuild it to its current state is amazing.

The church just kind of jumps out at you, while walking through the town. It's right in the middle of the shopping area, so we didn't even notice it until it was literally right in our face. What a great surprise. The city seemed to have lots of not-so-little surprises as you
If you don't tire of visiting churches in Germany, go into this one too. For us it was a wonder ful landmark for the Ubahn station nearest our hotel.
Found it different being Lutheran. Nice stained glass windows. A bit more austere than catholic churches.

This was one of the most moving experiences of my life. Two huge Christmas trees and over 100 candles whilst a choir was singing Silent Night in German, had me openly weeping for a long time. Beautiful!

This badly damaged cathedral has been restored in part, with a nod to the destruction and uselessness of war. It stands as a profound anti-war statement as the inside floor is nearly empty, in part so that the space can be reconfigured according to the needs of the churchand in
St Lorenz is a beautiful example of Gothic architecture. Construction began 1250 and took more than 200 years to complete. Parts of the church were destroyed during WWII
This medieval Church was damaged during World War II and restored later. Located in the old part of Nuerenberg.
Not much to say other than this is amazing architecture and a must see. Very near the market area of town. Sometimes can't get in due to service
Almost entirely rebuilt, a must see. The artwork and it's representations were great. Just wish there were more descriptions in English.
The carvings and the stained glass were amazing. Located in the market it is the central attraction.
The church contains much find artwork, including 3 or 4 triptychs and an excellent wood carving. The church is early 15th c. but was badly damaged in WW2 and later restored.

charming large church with great history....amazing to see the before and after pictures on inside of church....worth a visit
What a rebuild! Interesting prior and post reconstruction photos. Sizeable space, in active worship status.

...it is a place to be visited when you are in Altstadt, Nuernberg, Germany. Old and very solid construction as most of the buildings are in that part of the city.

If you got the time, make sure to stop by. The inside is just as awesome looking as the outside. Lots of cool stained glass and amazing architecture, well worth the 10 minutes to just look around and take pictures.

Any visit to Nuremberg is not complete without a visit to Lorenz church.. Easy to locate..just take U1 subway train to lorenzkirche stop which is next to the hbf. The atmosphere is amazing and the shops in the area are very interesting as well :) Definitely one of the unique

This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. Large and cavernous it has an aura of its own. Windows damaged in the Second World War have been replaced with clear glass to distinguish between old and new: whilst at the same time emphasising the whole. A
and my fave too. Its the Protestant Cathedral anyway, n it stands tall dividing the beautiful pedistrian shopping area.

Very moving experience to see the damage done to the cathedral and the process of reconstructing. While some of the larger signage has English, most of the details are only in German. Well-worth a visit.
Very pretty church in central Nuremberg. Well worth a visit inside if you have the time. Great for photos from the outside.
Similar architecture and features to other churches I saw around Germany and Austria. No entry fee is charged and fewer tourists than the more famous churches.
This old church is situated in the middle of the old town an it is a very nice example of architecture.
This is a beautiful, ornate, imposing, historic, awe inspiring, towering, divine piece of architecture. Go see it if you are in Nuremberg.

A svelte medieval cathedral, destroyed in World War Two by Allied bombs and rebuilt latter. Much taller and larger than its catholic "counterpart" Frauenkirche, also a Gothic jewel situated nearby. If you love medieval religious symbolism you can admire the outside and inside

I have seen many chatedral all over europe. I dont know if this is just me but this one is one of the most beautifull chatedrale in europe. I was impressed the first year and I m still impressed even if i m coming in Nurnberg every year for 15th years already. I even spent some

Stopping at St. Lorenz Church is a must when visiting the old city of Nurnberg. Seeing the beautiful outside of the church does not prepare you for the beauty on display on the inside. It is more than you could ever imagine. You can feel the presence of holiness.
Free to pay as much you like upon entry. Stuffed with pieces of medieval art. Very cold inside, be well dressed :) Free to take photos, close access to artworks
Christmas Market is definitely worth a visit! However it was very crowded during the weekends...................................
Very serene and peaceful setting with load and loads of history. easy to find and access is free. a must see for travellers
This medieval church has a great atmosphere, beautiful stained glass windows and intricately carved pews.

The church itself is well worth the trip without the organ music, but the music will change the experience entirely. Explore the church - the first thing I discovered was a 15th century altar. There are such treasures all around the church. I went for a 2 hour organ concert (I
One of the many impressive Churches in Nürnberg . Lovely to see with all the Christmas lights. Take a walk round you will be impressed.
Great stone work inside, impressive looking from the outside. Bright inside for a gothic style church. Must visit if in Nuremberg.

If you are Protestant and in Nuremberg on Christmas Eve, you will regret it if you miss this service. The organ music was magnificent and the architecture stunning, although a bit difficult to see at the 11pm Christmas Eve. Service. The parishioners were welcoming of non German

I'm fascinated by church architecture and I loved St Lorenz with its soaring gothic columns reaching like a forest of stone palm trees to the roof way above. Add in outstanding quality carving in wood and stone and fine mediaeval/renaissance art and I believe you have a place
Very beautiful place. If you like to take photos must go. Near MTR station and train station and can go to other church's by foot.

I stopped by to visit around noon today and saw a notice about a concert beginning in 15 minutes! It was lovely! Lots of people stopped to enjoy the music in the beautiful church. I have to say it was colder sitting inside than walking outside! Don't miss this church.
Go in a light a candle in this beautiful church. Take 5 minutes in solitude to count your blessings.

You can't miss this church. It seems to dominate the skyline everywhere you walk around the old town. The architecture is amazing. Nice sculptures. Very quiet and dark, but you can take pictures. One of the nicer churches to be found.

This is, without a doubt, a very beautiful church. I don't recommend you plan on staying the entire day, just pop in, check it out, and off you go. It's amazing, like all the other churches, but there's nothing that stands out about it.

This church sits on the Konigstrasse or King's Street near the Old Town center. It can easily be seen from some distance due to the tall twin towers that flank the main entrance. The church is best viewed outside from the west side where you face the masterful façade head-on.
Centrally located and very well preserved church with terrific historical works of art. An easy and worthwhile stop while touring the town.
You will see this church, this is in the middle of Konigstrasse, the main road. Very beautiful... Go and take pictures without flash.

There are two churches off of the main square in Old Town. Visit this one. It is archetecturally more interesting and better decorated inside. Their Madonna With Child actually looks like the Madonna likes the kid, and the Child looks like a normal happy baby.

This is one of a number of churches in Nuremberg. It was light and very welcoming. There were two places where you can purchase a tea light to remember a loved one. One was wall mounted and the other was in a corner and had sand covering the floor enabling you to write a name or

This is one of the oldest Protestant churches in Germany. It is very dark inside and hard to make out the furnishings. They have a beautiful cache set up and you can light a candle for €.50 to remember your loved ones at Christmastime. it is in the middle if the Christmas
This church has some nice paintings and sculptures. It is a quiet place away from the outside noise. I was not long here... maybe 15 minutes. Some people may need longer.

Sunday morning at 9:50 it begins, and depending upon the song of the day it may start with a single bell tone or a chromed of bells. Soon ringing over the city is a song to call to worship, a song of joy. It is worthy of a few minutes of reflection. The church is a
A nice church in the middle of downtown plaza just at the foothills of the upward slope that takes you to the famous Nuremberg Castle. Well decorated and quiet service.
One of the most beautiful churches in Germany. The stained glass windows are remarkable. This cathedral is definitely worth an hour or two visit.
Church was very beautiful with lots of stained glass windows. History was interesting and restoration was very remarkable.
The church is under construction when we are there. Inside it is quite beautiful but the fact construction equipment here really annoyed the tourist.

A medieval church built from 1243 to 1315 as a 3 aisled basilica in Gothic style. The nave was created in 1400 and the Choir from 1439 to 1477 by Konrad Roriczer. During the Reformation the city council fortunately took the decision to keep all the precious treasures of this

This lovely church was undergoing some construction during our visit so we didn't get to see everything, but iit's quite interesting, albeit stark, inside. Unfortunately, there's no real guide (at least in English) to understand what it is you're seeing, except it's very old,

A glorious gothic church with beautiful carvings and a lovely atmosphere, made all the more poignant when you see pictures of the destruction in the war. It's delicate and awe inspiring. It was busy but not overcrowded and there was no entry fee.

It is an old gothic church in the center of city and the surrounding are is also quite nice. This is one of the typical church in German style. Inside is common like others but you certainly should see the architectural construction.
One of the most beautiful churches in Nuremberg that I saw, loved everything about, the alter, statues

A medieval church with an impressive architecture. It was severely damaged during the WWII but it was restored almost to its original status afterwards. You will appreciate the great artwork in the stained glass windows, the ceiling and the sculptures .

I am not one to visit church's normally but this place is certainly worth a drop in, you are free to walk around and take in the great artwork and architecture of the building and don't forget to look up the ceiling is amazing. The stain glass windows are pretty impressive too

This is one of the most interesting gothic churches of Germany. It dates from the 14th century and contains an amazing number of artworks, which would be sufficient to fill-up an entire museum: paintings, polyptychs, winged altarpieces, stained glass windows, wooden and stone
Historical and rare example of a Bavarian church. This a must see for everyone visiting Nuremberg. Enter and be seated in order to experience this beautiful structure.

Very interesting old Church one of the attractions in Nuremberg right on the Lorenzer Platz with a lot of shops, restaurants and Christmas market in the winter. You can take a brake here for an ice cream or beer in the summer or for a mulled wine with cinnamon in the winter.
Pictures of the devastation after the 2nd world war are unbelievable.Beautiful re built church. Loved the square around the church
Beautiful church with the loveliest Christmas crib. Luethran so not highly decorated but very nice if you enjoy less grand churches. Information available in multiple languages
I love this church because of the Viet Stoss carving hanging in the apse. The craftsmanship is delicate but compelling. It is easy to see details because of tall gothic windows.
A beautiful church, with a special atmosphere inside. Splendid woodworks. A place where one wants to sit and contemplete the past. Renovation and reconstruction works still inside.
Evangelical Lutheran Church, XV century. The church has three organs, cheep entrance to beautiful organ masterpieces. Must listen.
One of the most prominent churches of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in Bavaria, is this magnificent Gothic style church in the centre of the Medieval city of Nuremberg...

A visit to the Lorenzkirche is a must in Nürnberg, it has a lot of important art. The world famous "Engelsgruss" from Veit Stoss hanging from the roof is alone worth a visit. It has also a very big organ from 1937, and 2 more organs. At 4pm there is 30 min organ concert playing
Walking through town, this church is a must see! Acoustics are wonderful, and the architecture outside is simply amazing!

When you are in the city it is just one of those places you have to visit. It doesn't matter if you are religious, neither does it matter if you enjoy old or new building, you just have to see this place in all it glory
Lovely walk around this historic castle, easy to access from the city centre with beautiful views of the old town.

I've visited St. Lorenz Kirche many times and always find it to be a powerful experience. It is located in the centre of busy,cosmopolitan Nuremburg but to step inside is to shed centuries. Architecturally, it is amazing. The accoustics are wonderful. On my most recent visit,
Definitely worth seeing if you are in Nuremberg, especially the huge "Engelsgruss" (Angelus) above the altar. One of the prime sites to see in Nuremberg.
Beautiful church and worth the visit. We were lucky as someone was playing organ when we arrived and it sounded great.
Quality exhibits at its best. Audio guide available in many languages, so it is easy to understand about the prominence of the place.

We visited about four or five of the main churches in the centre of Nuremberg and this was by far the most interesting in terms of architecture and iconography. Lots of very interesting pictures, windows and icons around the church, and a very peaceful atmosphere in the centre

Be sure not to miss this stunning beauty. If the outside attracts you the inside will absolutely captivate you. It is difficult to leave once there for fear of not taking the beauty with you. I was in awe.

I could have spent all day here, beautiful and amazing!!!! While there, a volunteer approached me and gave me information about the church and the history of some of the art and statues. The Epitaphs were spectacular!

Indeed, the hcurch is extremely magnificent both from the outside and the inside. There is a lot to be seen including pictures and sculptures. It is nicely located in the center so it easily accessible and doesn't take a lot to just take a look at it inside.

Just minutes from the square is this wonderful house of God. So much history and so much to see...just minutes from the underground and all the central shopping of old town. Please have respect inside this house of God and be quiet so all can enjoy the beauty and history.

i like old building & i like the design of this church. St. Lorenz church in Lorenzer Platz 10, Nuremberg. this church in Nuremberg center & close to shopping area. this church also amazing inside & it chance to know about Gothic &, it is one of the few Lutheran churches

The church has an impressive exterior and rhe details that make up the front of the church are very impressive. Interior is dark but worth a few minutes visit as you stroll around the shopping area outside. Stained glass is also worth a few minutes to examine the details.

This church is amazing inside, and it is one of the few Lutheran churches we saw on our trip through southern Germany. Take a quick peek inside, you won't be disappointed.
An absolutely beautiful building with near impossible detail. The renovation work that has taken place is a testiment to those involved!
Considering it was bombed during the war this has been painstakingly renovated. As is mentioned in other reviews you can't help but be impressed by the sight.

When you walk into the square you cannot help but marvel at the vasade. The gothic architecture is fantastic and it is deceptively tall. Inside it is cold an plain, bearing in mind the City was flattened by llied bombing, the interior had to be re-built. Worth a visit and it's

This Church is a great masterpiece, it's worth visiting by all gothic style lovers and people who would like to see something new ;) Even though there are plenty of catholic churches around Europe, this one has a couple of curious pieces inside, so just go and see them with your

Even if St. Lorenz Church isn't on your Nuremberg itinerary, it's well worth the few minutes is takes to locate, just up the hill from the main square. The interior is very impressive, but if you're lucky enough to be around an organ recital or concert, don't miss that

Good view of a Gothic Middle age cathedral. Missed the organ, sure must be awesome to hear. I always leave a small donation at least. be aware of non-tourist times during services.
